body: It seems to me to be working properly.
@kamarton It only works when you configured the request component accordingly, but this could be done out of the box as LB's provide those informations already without configure anything.
@kamarton You should not create app that trusts every host. Moreover my issue is about different situation than you presented.

> You should not create app that trusts every host.

If something has done the IP resolv then it has to be accepted, therefor on the role of `trustedHosts` is only that what comes in is automatically accepted as secure ->` 0.0.0.0/0`.

> The ngx_http_realip_module module is used to change the client address and optional port to those sent in the specified header field.

"change the client address" - The `trustedHosts` function gets an resolved IP address. It's will no longer be able to manage trust (`0.0.0.0/0`).

Cases:
- IP already resolved: resolved based on this PR with trustedHost=0.0.0.0/0 (It was sufficient to improve the use of the `getUserIp()` function.)
- no IP resolv at all: normal use of `trustedHost`
- no need for IP resolv: no need to use `trustedHost`
- there is not always a IP resolv: custom development is not covered by the framework. Otherwise, it makes no sense to talk about resolving, because it is not possible to determine when resolving occurs, which implies that `getUserIP()`, secure headers and so on. nor can it be resolved.

> Moreover my issue is about different situation than you presented.

Real example with input and output data?

1. `getIsSecureConnection()` is likely wrong that it first checks `$_SERVER` and only then falls back to secure headers. If headers are trusted then they should be preferred. Current code should fail if client is using HTTP but load balancer uses HTTPS to communicate to Yii2 App.
2. There is no way to automatically determine if host is a trusted load balancer. Yii should not trust header-based values by default.

issue.title: Network resolver instead of operate with REMOTE ADDR and more

body:
> getIsSecureConnection() is likely wrong that it first checks $_SERVER and only then falls back to secure headers. If headers are trusted then they should be preferred. Current code should fail if client is using HTTP but load balancer uses HTTPS to communicate to Yii2 App.

I think there is little point in further developing this in Yii2. If you set up IP resolving on your web server (e.g `ngx_http_realip_module`), you can obviously assume that you trust it. This is equivalent to using `trustedHosts = [0.0.0.0/0]`. This is actually a kind of use of the `turstedHosts` functionality.

However, if you enable `trustedHost = [0.0.0.0/0]`, it will try to re-resolv the user's IP address based on `X-Forwarded-For` (the web server cannot be expected to delete this header). The PR improve this. (https://github.com/yiisoft/yii2/pull/17569)

The https://github.com/yiisoft/yii-web/issues/119 issue allows you to define additional network resolver classes for such cases, but for Yii2 this would only add more complexity to the `Request` class, which is unreasonable in terms of resolving the problem.
What would you recommend to configure my application when i have a load balancer which can change the IP Adresse every time like my VM instance does? `'secureHeaders' => [],` might be even worse.
@nadar depends on if what's behind load balancer is accessible directly or not.
